In that situation, Moodyâ€™s would in particular focus on any change in the financial value of debt obligations relative to the original contractual promise. Over to the US and - in news which will not please Donald Trump - the countryâ€™s trade deficit in January widened to its highest level since March 2012. With rising oil prices pushing up the cost of imported fuel, the trade gap increased 9.6% to $48.5bn compared to the December figure of $44.3bn, according to the Commerce Department. Trump sees trade as one of the key areas to tackle, and has already said he will pull out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership and renegotiated the North American Free Trade Agreement. Exports to the European Union fell 7.3%, and Trump advisors have already hit out at Germany for benefiting from a weak euro. The trade deficit with the United Kingdom rose from $457m to $609m. Meanwhile the deficit with China, another contentious area for Trump, rose by 12.8% to $31.1bn in January. But the trade deficit with Mexico - where Trump has continued to push plans for a border wall - fell 10.1% to its lowest level since July 2015. Hereâ€™s our news story about Charlotte Hoggâ€™s non-disclosure, which sparked such a rumpus at the Treasury committee today: Newsflash: John Mann MP has declare that Charlotte Hoggâ€™s position as deputy governor is â€œnow untenableâ€�, following her admission that she didnâ€™t declare that her brother hold a senior role in Barclaysâ€™ strategy team. In a statement just released, Mann MP argues that Hogg has failed to meet the principles of public life, known as the â€œNolan principlesâ€� (a point he made during todayâ€™s hearing). Mann says: â€œIt is simply incredible that such a senior person at the Bank of England has behaved in such in this manner. Last week Charlotte Hogg proudly told this committee that she actually wrote the bankâ€™s code of conduct which she has now admitted to repeatedly breaking it.â€� â€œNot only has she compromised her current position and the Bank of England itself but more importantly she has failed under the key principles of the Nolan standards in public life and she has no excuse for doing so.â€� â€œThis is simply a question about standards in public life and in this regard she has failed and must resign.â€� You can watch the entire Treasury Committee hearing about Charlotte Hoggâ€™s non-declaration here. Andrew Tyrie wraps up the hearing by saying that we are â€œlooking at a mistake, a series of mistakesâ€�. We need to examine if the response from the bank has been proportionate. There are three issues to discuss, Tyrie argues: Whether, and to what extent, we can ensure this doesnâ€™t become a case of â€˜do what I say, not what I doâ€™ for a very serious member of the Bank Need to protect the reputation of the Bankâ€™s Prudential Regulation Committee, which oversees UK banks What it says about the role of the Court in the Bankâ€™s governance. Tyrie concludes by telling Anthony Habgood and Bradley Fried that this morningâ€™s news about Charlotte Hogg has been a surprise to a number of committee members, including himself, and they must â€œthink very carefullyâ€� about it. Charlotte Hogg has also officially recorded her family links to the Hoare family -- who created Britainâ€™s oldest private bank, Habgood says. Q: Have any other senior Bank of England staff updated their declarations under the code of conduct since Charlotte Hoggâ€™s omission came to light? Anthony Habgood says that several people have, yes, including one who has added that his daughter is a political journalist. Deputy court chairman Bradley Fried now hits back at the suggestion that Charlotte Hoggâ€™s conduct has fallen below acceptable standards. Despite this lack of disclosure over her brother, I believe she is a â€œsuperb public servantâ€� says Fried. His personal view is that Hogg does meet standards of the best of public life laid out in the code. We are living with the â€œdisappointment and aggravationâ€� of her non-disclosure right now, Fried adds. And he suggests this affair will be a â€œwatershed momentâ€� in Hoggâ€™s career, and also in the way that senior Bank executives report any potential conflicts of interest. Scottish Nationalist Party MP George Kerevan reads out the Bankâ€™s code of conduct. Q: The code of conduct on interests says that â€œliving within our code is not simply about observing the letter of the policies referred to. We aspire to set an example of the best in public service.â€� By that test, has Ms Hogg failed it? BoE Court chairman Anthony Habgood replies that She has omitted something that she should not have omitted, that is important, so she has not lived up to that code. Q: So do you stand by the code? Absolutely we stand by the code, Habgood adds. Q: What effect will her non-compliance have on the rest of the bank staff, and the way they see the code? We will push the code harder, Habgood says, but it is hard as it relies on self-assessment. For example, someoneâ€™s second son might move from a non-regulated City firm to a regulated one - so theyâ€™d need to update their records. We have moved a long way from a few years ago, when the Bank didnâ€™t really have a code of conduct, Habgood adds (somewhat alarmingly!) Tory MP Kit Malthouse is concerned that the Bank of England doesnâ€™t know exactly what Quintin Hogg does at Barclays. He could even be targeted with handling Barclayâ€™s strategy towards the Bank of England, Malthouse suggests. We could find out, Habgood concedes. But even if that were the case, he thinks it wouldnâ€™t have affected Charlotte Hoggâ€™s suitability to be deputy governor. Now the committee ask about social ties between the top brass at the Bank of England. Court chairman Anthony Habgood insists that heâ€™s had no social interaction with Charlotte Hogg -- beyond one trip to â€œsomething to do with ballet for youthful peopleâ€�. I didnâ€™t know her until just before I came to the bank. But Habgood then reveals other ties to the Hogg dynasty. I know her mother better than I know her because sheâ€™s been chairman of various things when Iâ€™ve been chairman of various things. Charlotte Hoggâ€™s mother is Sarah Hogg, the first woman to chair a FTSE 100 company (3i, back in 2002). Sheâ€™s married to Douglas Martin Hogg, son of the late Lord Hailsham, and a former Tory MP (until his expenses claim for moat-cleaning came to light...) Fried adds: Anthony [Habgood]and I are fans of Charlotte. We think sheâ€™s a distinctive professional. Conservative MP Kit Malthouse wants to know what the Court of the Bank of England (the board of the central bank) is going to do about Hoggâ€™s breach of the code. Deputy chairman Bradley Fried says the situation will be discussed. Clearly we have an issue now around optics. We hope that it can be resolved. Itâ€™s not an issue how we feel individually. We will discuss it in full Court. Chairman Anthony Habgood then weighs in, saying they donâ€™t expect to recommend reversing Hoggâ€™s appointment as deputy governor of the BoE. Why not, asks Tyrie? Because the process of having Hoggâ€™s line manager (Mark Carney), and the head of HR looking into the issue has been concluded, Habgood explains. Earlier in this hearing, deputy court chairman Bradley Fried said Hogg had committed an â€œunwillful act of omission.â€� Bloomberg has the details: â€œI definitely donâ€™t believe itâ€™s a hanging offence,â€� Fried told Parliament Tuesday. â€œItâ€™s terribly unfortunate. It warrants grumpiness.â€� Anthony Habgood says he has discussed the situation with governor Mark Carney -- apparently it was a â€œrevelationâ€� to Carney that Charlotte Hogg hadnâ€™t declared her brotherâ€™s role at Barclays. Committee chairman Andrew Tyrie wants more answers from BoE chairman Anthony Habgood. Q: How many breaches of the Bankâ€™s code of conduct are there? Habgood doesnâ€™t know. I think it might be helpful to know, Tyrie points out. Q: What are the sanctions for failing to make a voluntary declaration? It depends on the seriousness of it, Habgood says. In most cases, heâ€™d expect that the line manager and the HR department would speak to the individual and take a view. Q: So why didnâ€™t Charlotte Hogg declare her brotherâ€™s role as a Barclays strategy director when she was hired as chief operating officer in 2013? Habgood insists that it wasnâ€™t a â€œwilfulâ€� decision. He suggests that Hogg didnâ€™t feel that her brother was in a position where it mattered - which was a mistake as she she shouldnâ€™t take that decision. It was also an issue of priorities but it should have been high up her list of priorities as Charlotte Hogg helped develop the codes, Habgood points out... Labour MP John Mann is now laying into the Bank of Englandâ€™s top brass -- comparing Charlotte Hoggâ€™s conduct to MPs who were jailed in the expenses scandal. The standards of public life are about ethics and public responsibility, Mann insists. He demands to know who is going to â€œsanctionâ€� Hogg for not declaring her brotherâ€™s role at Barclays back in 2013. Mann tells BoE Court chairman Anthony Habgood that: Sheâ€™s broken the standards in public life....and youâ€™ve done nothing about it.... You must see that the independence of the Court is being brought into question. Habgood says any sanction is the responsibility of her line manager, governor Mark Carney. And he points out that Hogg did declare her brotherâ€™s role to the committee in her written submission last month (itâ€™s online here). The problem, though, is that she didnâ€™t declare it back in 2013 when she joined the Bank. Habgood says: The standard is broken, that is correct. But he argues that this isnâ€™t a â€˜black and whiteâ€™ issue -- the Court must consider a range of factors (Hogg is highly regarded at the BoE). And there is definitely no personal gain here, Habgood insists. The Treasury Committee are laying into the Bank of Englandâ€™s top brass over Charlotte Hoggâ€™s failure to declare that her brother works for Barclays. Jacob Rees-Mogg (who knows a thing or two about high society), is challenging the idea that there hasnâ€™t been a conflict of interest, actual or potential. There arenâ€™t a lot of people in the City called Quintin Hogg, points out Rees-Mogg. He adds: Whatâ€™s worrying me is that the bank and the Court is pretty complacent about this. It canâ€™t have been wrong because we wouldnâ€™t have behaved like that. We wonâ€™t investigate it - weâ€™ll just say thereâ€™s no conflict because the brotherâ€™s probably like us, heâ€™s another good chap. Rees-Mogg is also unimpressed that Anthony Habgood doesnâ€™t seem to actually know what Hogg. Q does at Barclays. Deputy chairman Bradley Fried hits back at the suggestion that the Bank is a cushy institution where family background counts for a lot. Weâ€™re a â€œdeeply forensic, fact-based institutionâ€� he insists. Now this is awkward.... Charlotte Hogg, the newly appointed deputy governor of the Bank of England, has admitted that she failed to disclose that her brother works for Barclays Bank. Itâ€™s a clear, and highly embarrassing, breach of the BoEâ€™s code of conduct. Last month, Hogg told MPs Treasury Committee that she had reported her brotherâ€™s role as a strategy director at Barclays to the Bank, when she joined as its chief operating officer in 2013. But now, in a letter to the Treasury Committee released this morning, Hogg admits that she didnâ€™t. Hereâ€™s the key section: During my appointment hearing on 28 February 2017,1 was asked by you and other members of the Committee about my brotherâ€™s role as Director, Group Strategy at Barclays Bank pic. Following my hearing, I checked the Bankâ€™s records of the interests and relationships that I had declared prior to joining the Bank in July 2013 and subsequently. I had not formally declared my brotherâ€™s role at Barclays Bank pic to the Bank. The first time that I formally outlined my brotherâ€™s role was when I noted it in the questionnaire which I submitted to the Committee in advance of my recent hearing. As Barclays Bank pic is regulated by the PRA, under the Bankâ€™s internal code of conduct and personal relationships policy, I should have formally declared my brotherâ€™s role when I first joined the Bank. I did not do so and I take full responsibility for this oversight. I have now added a full record of my brotherâ€™s role in the Bankâ€™s HR systems. Regrettably, my oversight means that my oral evidence to the Committee in this respect was not accurate. I write now to correct that evidence at the earliest opportunity and to place on record my sincere apologies to the Committee. Hogg adds that the Secretary of the Bank and the Chaiman of the Bankâ€™s Court of Directors, Anthony Habgood, agree that there has not been any actual or potential conflict of interest. But Andrew Tyrie, the chair of the Treasury committee, isnâ€™t impressed at all. Heâ€™s quizzing Habgood about the issue now in parliament. Tyrie argues that this relationship becomes a â€œmuch more serious issueâ€� now that Hogg has been promoted to deputy governor. And doesnâ€™t this breach show how seriously the Bank does (or doesnâ€™t) take its approach to compliance? Habgood agrees that this is â€œa very serious breachâ€� of the Bankâ€™s compliance code.... Economics blogger Tim Worstall has a good take on the German factory orders decline, on Forbes. Hereâ€™s a flavour: Reading too much into just the one monthâ€™s numbers is not a sensible thing to be doing so the answer to that headline question, as Betteridgeâ€™s Law says it should be, is probably no. However, when matters do turn against the German economy this is the sort of thing that we would expect to see. We all know, or at least we all should know, that the German economy is rather different from those of other advanced countries. It has about double the manufacturing of those others and that manufacturing is rather more concentrated into durable goods than most others. Itâ€™s thus vulnerable to a slow down in investment in other economies... More here: Itâ€™s a bad morning for hundreds of workers at Budgens stores across the country. Some 34 Budgens stores are closing after administrators failed to find a buyer for their owner, Food Retailer Operations Limited (FROL). These stores employ around 815 workers. However (and contrary to some reports), this doesnâ€™t mean that the entire Budgens chain is toast. Instead, around 150 other outlets are still in business. Charles Wilson, chief executive of Booker, told my colleague Julia Kollewe that: â€œThe business is performing very strongly.â€� Budgens stores are usually run by independent retailers, while the brand is owned by Bookers -- which is being taken over by Tesco. Breaking: The OECD thinktank has just become the latest organisation to admit that it overestimated the impact of the Brexit vote on the UK economy. The Paris-based group now expects Britainâ€™s GDP to rise by 1.6% this year, up from 1.2% previously. My colleague Katie Allen says itâ€™s a boost to chancellor Philip Hammond ahead of tomorrowâ€™s budget. The new forecasts envisage the UK economy performing in line with the eurozone economy, where GDP is also expected to expand by 1.6% in 2017. The US economy, helped in part by an expected rise in spending under Donald Trumpâ€™s administration, is forecast to grow 2.4% this year. The OECD still has concerns about the UK economy, and is warning that inflation will hurt growth. More here: The news that UK house price growth has hit its lowest level since July 2013 has disappointed some economists. Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight predicts that the market will be muted in 2017: Februaryâ€™s slight rise in house prices reported by the Halifax fuels our belief that house price gains over 2017 will be no more than 3% and could well be less. Weakening consumer fundamentals, likely mounting caution over making major spending decisions, and elevated house price to earnings ratios are likely to weigh down on house prices. However, a shortage of supply is likely to put a hard floor under prices. Jonathan Hopper, managing director of Garrington Property Finders, says potential buyers are being cautious: â€œHalifaxâ€™s latest data reflects the cautious nature of the market; with value sensitive buyers remaining committed to their moving plans, but only at the right price. Hannah Maundrell, Editor in Chief of money.co.uk, doesnâ€™t believe weâ€™re heading for a crash: â€œItâ€™s too soon to make a call on whether the property market is cooling off. While itâ€™s possible this is a sign of things to come demand is still so high and supply so lacking so I canâ€™t see a dramatic slump on the horizon quite yet. â€œAffordability is a major issue and if rising inflation means households are strapped for cash getting onto or moving up the ladder will be more difficult and that will impact prices. The changes to tax on rental properties have also meant more would-be landlords are holding back from buying too which has an effect. Rob Weaver, Director of Investments at property crowdfunding platform Property Partner, thinks the lack of housing supply will keep propping prices up. â€œDespite continuing uncertainty, a buoyant jobs market, record low interest rates and the imbalance between high demand for homes and a severe shortage in supply continue to put upward pressure on prices. Britainâ€™s house market appears to be weakening, with prices growing at their weakest rate in over three years. Prices rose by an annual rate of 5.1% in the three months to February, according to the Halifax building society. Thatâ€™s down from 5.7% the previous month, and the weakest rate since July 2013. In February alone, prices inched up by 0.1% - weaker than the 0.4% expected by City economists. Halifaxâ€™s Martin Ellis predicts that price growth will keep falling, bringing it closer to wage growth. Ellis says: â€œA sustained period of house price growth in excess of pay rises has made it increasingly difficult for many to purchase a home. This development, together with signs of reduced momentum in the jobs market and squeezed consumer spending power, is expected to curb house price growth during 2017.â€� These factory orders numbers are rather weaker than other German data, points out Bloomberg: Ifoâ€™s business climate index improved in February amid strong activity in manufacturing and services, and unemployment continued to decline. And last week, we got very decent PMI figures suggesting that German factories were â€˜hummingâ€™ in March.. Even if you strip out orders for expensive transport equipment, German factories had a bad January: Financial analysts are concerned by the scale of the drop in German factory orders at the start of 2017. Carsten Brzeski at ING says the 7.4% slide is â€œalmost unprecedentedâ€�, â€œTodayâ€™s disappointing data is also a good reminder that the German industry is having more problems returning to full speed than buoyant sentiment indicators have been suggestingâ€�. Fred Ducrozet of Swiss bank Pictet points out that demand for large machinery and expensive equipment (known as capital goods) fell particularly rapidly Claus Vistesen of Pantheon says the figures are â€˜horribleâ€™, but doesnâ€™t want to read too much into a single monthâ€™s data. Andreas WallstrÃ¶m of Nordea Markets provides more context: Germanyâ€™s manufacturing sector has suffered a surprisingly sharp fall in orders, raising concerns that its economy may not be as robust as thought. Orders for German factory goods plunged by 7.4% in January, compared to December. Thatâ€™s much worse than the 2.5% drop which analysts expected. The dropoff appears to have been driven by a decline in orders within Germany itself. This domestic demand fell by 10.5%. Foreign orders slid by 4.9% -- including a 7.8% fall in demand from the euro zone. Thatâ€™s not a great signal for the euro area, which had shown signs of more robust growth recently. We shouldnâ€™t read TOO much into one monthâ€™s data -- especially as the German factory orders report is notoriously volatile... Germanyâ€™s finance ministry is urging calm, saying: â€œThe weak start to the year should be manageable. Business confidence in manufacturing is significantly brighter than the long-term average, so that a revival in manufacturing can still be expected.â€� Iâ€™ll pull together more reaction now.... Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. Consumer spending has been propping the UK economy up since last summerâ€™s EU referendum. But there are now signs that the retail sector is feeling a chill. A new survey this morning shows that retail sales slid by 0.2% in the three months to February, compared with a year earlier. Non-food sales are dropping for the first time in five years, suggesting consumers are tightening their belts as the economy slows. Helen Dickinson of the British Retail Consortium, which compiled the report, warns: â€œTougher times are expected ahead. The impact of inflation on consumer spending will add further intensity to an already fiercely competitive environment in which the ability to adapt and innovate will be key to survival.â€� Faced with slowing sales, retailers are now pleading with the government to rethink its business rates changes - perhaps as soon as in tomorrowâ€™s Budget? Also coming up today..... We get a new healthcheck on the global economy at 10am GMT, with the latest forecasts from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). The car industry has flocked to Geneva for the annual Motor Show, where theyâ€™ll be showing off new models and concept cars. Closer to home, Vauxhall car workers will be thinking about the future after being sold by General Motors yesterday. PSA Group, their new owners, has promised that job cuts arenâ€™t inevitable. But although Vauxhallâ€™s two UK plants are relatively efficient, they could still lose out. My colleague Graham Ruddick explains: Vauxhallâ€™s factories in Ellesmere Port and Luton will have to battle with Peugeot, CitroÃ«n, and Opel plants across Europe to win the right to produce vehicles beyond 2021. The future of Vauxhallâ€™s sites is secure until then because PSA Group, which has bought Vauxhall and Opel from General Motors, has pledged to recognise existing production commitments. Ellesmere Port is scheduled to produce the Astra until 2021 while Luton will make the Vivaro van until 2025. However, PSA will have to make a decision on where to produce the next-generation Astra from 2021 as early as next year, and Ellesmere Port faces a significant challenge to win the work and secure its survival.... More here: European stock markets are expected to rally a little, pushing the FTSE 100 back towards last weekâ€™s record highs. On the corporate news front, bookmaker Paddy Power, online food delivery form Just Eat and insurance firm Direct Line are reporting results. And Halifax are scheduled to release their latest UK house price figures, at 8.30am GMT. Weâ€™ll be tracking all the main events through the day...

fields.body:
3.51pm GMT

Thatâ€™s all for today.

Hereâ€™s AFPâ€™s take on the ECB press conference.

The European Central Bank reported signs of an improving eurozone economy Thursday, but said it would keep cheap money gushing for fear of undermining the recovery.

ECB watchers were alert for any tightening of the ECBâ€™s ultra-loose policy as inflation rates rise and prospects for growth in the 19-nation single currency area improve.

The central bank has set interest rates at record lows and buys tens of billions of euros of bonds per month in a bid to drive up growth and inflation.

At the meeting of the bankâ€™s governing council â€œthere was a general recognition that the balance of risk has improved, certainly as far as growth is concerned,â€� ECB president Mario Draghi told reporters. â€œThere is no longer that sense of urgency in taking further actions.â€�

But â€œthis is a gradual process,â€� he went on at a Frankfurt press conference.

â€œThe governing council members want to be convinced they see a self-sustained adjustment in the inflation rateâ€� before closing the money sluices, he said.

For now, faced with uncertain impacts from global upheavals abroad and elections at home, the ECB plans to continue its bond-buying scheme until December as planned, as well as maintaining its commitment to interest rates â€œat present or lower levelsâ€� for the foreseeable future.

â€œSpring is coming and the ECB is celebrating,â€� judged analyst Florian Hense of Berenberg bank, while noting that, despite the lifting spirits, â€œit has not moved significantly closer to actually tightening policyâ€�....

Goodnight. GW

3.15pm GMT

Draghi press conference: What the experts say

Kathleen Brooks of City Index says Mario Draghi has proved he was the â€œking of curveballsâ€� at todayâ€™s press conference in Frankfurt.

After delivering what was arguably a dovish statement early on in his press conference, and clearly stating that for the ECBâ€™s GDP and inflation forecasts are conditional on the implementation â€œof all our policy measuresâ€�, Draghi displayed a more hawkish tone during the Q&A.

The key takeaway from this monthâ€™s ECB meeting appears contradictory: QE is here to stay in the Eurozone, until at least the end of this year. However, more policy action is less likely because deflation risks have receded. Reading between the lines suggests that the next change from the ECB will be towards removing accommodation and not adding it.

Aberdeen Asset Management investment manager Patrick Oâ€™Donnell says Draghi has given a small hint that the ECB could adjust its policy stance soon:

â€œDraghi has ever so slightly opened the door to changing their policy stance. Heâ€™s done this by saying that the Governing Council talked about changing the language about where rates are in their monthly statement, but didnâ€™t actually change it. This is effectively him signalling that something might change in the future, just not today.

â€œItâ€™s a classic Draghi technique of saying something that will move markets without actually doing anything. Due to this, and a wordy response to a question about raising rates before QE ends, markets will now start to recalibrate on the assumption that the ECB will remove accommodation towards the end of the year.â€�

Jamie Dutta, senior market analyst at Faraday Research, says the ECB president â€œflip-floppedâ€™ between his bearish opening statement, and some bullish remarks in the press conference.

The ECB and Mario Draghi celebrated its two year anniversary of its Asset Purchase Program by being marginally less dovish than expected in the monthly press conference. It was an interesting balancing act for Draghi between unchanged monetary policy stimulus policies and improved economic prospects. The market took the upgraded forecasts for growth and inflation in its stride.

However they reacted more positively when Draghi stated that there was no longer a â€˜sense of urgency on taking further actionsâ€™ to boost inflation and the recovery. Indeed Draghi further said the â€˜risks to deflation have largely disappearedâ€™.

And Pictetâ€™s Frederik Ducrozet shows how the ECB has raised its forecasts for inflation in 2017 and 2018:

2.45pm GMT

Draghi: The euro is here to stay

The press conference ends with Mario Draghi insisting that the euro is irrevocable, and not going to break up.

The ECB president declares that:

The euro is here to stay. Itâ€™s not about whether or not it is irrevocable. It is.

The ECB president calls the euro a â€œchannel for solidarityâ€� (which might rankle with those suffering financial plight in Greece).

Draghi points out that Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania all joined the single currency since the financial crisis began, due to the benefits of membership.

We need to make monetary union function better, Draghi adds, to increase prosperity in the region.

And this bullish talk has helped to push the euro up. Itâ€™s currently up 0.6% at $1.06.

Updated at 2.48pm GMT

2.29pm GMT

German bond prices are falling, driving up the yield on the debt.

Traders are reacting to the news that the ECB has dropped its pledge to use â€˜all available instrumentsâ€™ to achieve its mandate, and is now less worried about deflation.

2.28pm GMT

Mario Draghi is treading an interesting path at todayâ€™s press conference.

On the one hand, heâ€™s talking up the prospects for the eurozone economy and saying there is no longer a deflation risk.

But heâ€™s also warning that there are â€˜downside risksâ€™ that could derail the recovery.

Why? Because heâ€™s got a firm eye on upcoming elections, particularly in France.

2.24pm GMT

Q: Were todayâ€™s decisions unanimous?

Enigmatically, Draghi says the discussion was â€˜consensualâ€™.....

2.24pm GMT

Rather sweetly, Draghi suggests that itâ€™s 18 months since Britain voted to leave the EU.

Just nine, old boy. Although it sometimes feels like nine years...

2.20pm GMT

Draghi says the governing council did not discuss ending its QE programme, or boosting it, at todayâ€™s meeting.

2.20pm GMT

Mario Draghi sounds somewhat concerned about geopolitics, warning that global risks have risen recently.

We havenâ€™t yet seen negative consequences from the Brexit vote, he adds, but itâ€™s not clear how various â€˜risk eventsâ€™ will play out.

Updated at 2.52pm GMT

2.17pm GMT

Draghi is asked about the criticism of Germanyâ€™s trade surplus from Peter Navarro, trade advisor to Donald Trump, who argues that the euro is unfairly weak.

Draghi defends Berlin, saying he doesnâ€™t see any merit in attacking Germany.

Germanyâ€™s currency is the euro, and eurozone monetary policy is set for the whole region, he insists.

2.12pm GMT

Q: Could the ECB raise interest rates before it has ended its QE programme?

Draghi ducks the question. And thatâ€™s interesting, as heâ€™s previously insisted that rate would not rise until the asset-purchase programme had concludes.

2.08pm GMT

On deflation....Mario Draghi says that the risks have â€œlargely disappearedâ€�, adding:

Market-based inflation expectations have increased noticeably.

2.06pm GMT

Draghi: Sense of urgency has gone

In a hawkish move, the European central bank has dropped an important line from its statement.

The pledge to use â€œall the instruments at its disposalâ€� if necessary to achieve it mandates has been removed.

Mario Draghi says this has been dropped because the â€œsense of urgencyâ€� has gone, suggesting the ECB is less worried about the situation.

2.01pm GMT

ECB raises growth and inflation forecasts

Hello again. Sorry about that breakdown - while I was away, Mario Draghi has been speaking to the press in Frankfurt.

The ECB president has announced slightly higher growth forecasts; GDP is now expected to rise by 1.8% in 2017 (up from 1.7% in December) and by 1.6% in 2018 (up from 1.5%)

It has also raised its inflation forecast this year to 1.7% (from 1.3%).

Draghi still sound cautious, saying:

The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook have become less pronounced, but remain tilted to the downside and relate predominantly to global factors.

1.27pm GMT

Weâ€™re having a few technical issues here , so might miss the start of the ECB press conference #developing....

1.18pm GMT

German MEP criticises ECB for leaving rates on hold

Markus Ferber, a German conservative MEP, is unhappy that the European Central Bank didnâ€™t raise interest rates today.

Ferber argues that the ECB should have responded to the recent rise in euro area inflation, to 2%.

British workers are suffering the worst decade for pay growth since Arthur Wellesley was giving Napoleon Bonaparte a bloody nose at Waterloo. Thatâ€™s the verdict of the Resolution Foundation, which has crunched the numbers in yesterdayâ€™s budget. Director Torsten Bell says: â€œThe big picture from yesterdayâ€™s budget is that the big squeezes on both the public and family finances have been prolonged well into the 2020s. â€œWhile the Office for Budget Responsibility at least delivered some good news on borrowing, the family finances picture has actually deteriorated since the autumn statement. Britain is set for a return to falling real pay later this year, with this decade now set to be the worst for pay growth since the Napoleonic wars. Theyâ€™ve also calculated that, on current form, Britain wonâ€™t eliminate its deficit until 2025 - 15 years after George Osborneâ€™s first austerity budget. Todayâ€™s European Central Bank meeting is also overshadowed by presidential elections in France and the Netherlands. And thatâ€™s another reason for the ECB to sit tight today, argues Carsten Brzeski of ING: â€œWith headline inflation in the euro zone back at the magic 2 percent, the ECB hawks and critics will gradually sense that their moment has come to push for tapering. â€œIn our view, however, they will not want to add any new uncertainty in the eve of two important elections in the Eurozone.â€� Several experts are arguing that the European Central Bank should ignore calls to start winding back its stimulus programme. Guntram Wolff of the Bruegel thinktank says underlying inflationary pressures are still too weak: Kathleen Brooks of City Index predicts that the ECB wonâ€™t start to dial back its bond-buying programme until the autumn. We seem to have entered a post-inflation era for central bankers, who used to try and prevent price pressures from building. Now we tend to see a willingness for central banks, including the Bank of England, the ECB and, to a smaller extent, the Federal Reserve, to look through periods of high inflation in order to protect growth. Thus, the fact that headline CPI reached 2% is unlikely to deter the ECB from keeping rates in negative territory and maintaining asset purchases, potentially into 2018. We do expect the ECB to revise up its long-term inflation forecast at tomorrowâ€™s meeting, which could trigger some euro buying as the market anticipates a premature end to the ECBâ€™s QE programme. We also donâ€™t expect the ECB to announce any plans to taper its asset purchases any time soon. Firstly, growth in the region remains uneven, for example, the Greek economy contracted sharply at the end of 2016, Finnish growth was flat and Italy could only muster growth of 1%. These are economies that need support from their central bank, and even the German finance minister in a recent speech noted that the ECB was doing a good job to balance policy for all Eurozone members. We think that the ECB is approx. 6-months away from announcing a taper to its QE programme. Kit Juckes of Societe Generale predicts a â€˜straight batâ€™ from president Draghi: No policy change is expected....Mario Draghi will acknowledge the better economic backdrop and higher inflation, but avoid any watering-down of the dovish bias. Itâ€™s two years since the European Central Bank took the plunge and started stimulating the eurozone economy with newly created money. And just look how itâ€™s grown.... European stock markets have opened in the red, as investors await news from the ECB at lunchtime. Britainâ€™s FTSE 100 is the biggest faller, shedding 44 points or 0.6% to 7289 points. Morrisons is the biggest faller, down 5.5%. It warned this morning that there are uncertainties ahead, including the impact of the weak pound driving up imported food prices. Mining shares are down too. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. The European Central Bankâ€™s governing council may have a spring in its step today, as policymakers gather for their latest policy meeting in Frankfurt. After years of low inflation, the consumer prices index is finally back on target at 2% - meaning that fears of a deflationary spiral can be put to bed. But the ECB still has a problem; what to do about its massive stimulus programme that is pumping billions of euros into the eurozone each month? Hawkish members of the ECB will be putting pressure on president Mario Draghi to start the process of winding back its bond-buying QE programme. Theyâ€™d also like Draghi to signal that the interest rates could rise, having been slashed to record lows of zero (or lower, for banks who leave money in the ECBâ€™s vaults). Hereâ€™s the timings: 12.45pm GMT: ECB announce its decision on interest rates and QE 1.30pm GMT: Mario Draghi press conference The markets arenâ€™t expecting any new measures today; but the key, as so often with Draghi, is the language he uses. Analysts at RBC Capital Markets explain: The market will be watching for any changes to the ECBâ€™s language today, particularly whether it may drop its current bias toward lower interest rates which would likely be interpreted as a potential signal that the period of ultra-accommodative monetary policy is coming to an end, even if the ECB is still someway from signalling a readiness to raise rates. Our view is that the Governing Council will keep its forward guidance language as is for the time being pointing to the continued weakness of core inflation as justification. The ECB will also issue new staff forecasts on growth and inflation; these are likely to be revised higher. So itâ€™s likely to be a lively day in the currency markets: Also coming up today.... UK chancellor Philip Hammond will be busy defending yesterdayâ€™s budget, and the proposed rise in national insurance contributions for the self-employed. Tory MPs arenâ€™t happy about this apparent breach of the governmentâ€™s manifesto commitments, so it could be a long day for Hammond.... Supermarket chain Wm Morrison, the Co-operative Bank, Dominoâ€™s Pizza and estate agent Countrywide are reporting results. The John Lewis chain will be telling its staff the size of their annual bonus. Itâ€™s likely to be much smaller than in recent years, which explains why journalists arenâ€™t invited to this yearâ€™s event. Finance journalist Simon Neville (and his young apprentice) are disappointed... Weâ€™ll be tracking all the main events through the day...

fields.body:
6.19pm GMT

Finally, George Mudie MP asks if the possibility of Scotland breaking away from the UK will be modelled in the next OBR forecasts

Robert Chote replies that the OBR bases its work on UK government policy, so it all depends on the situation in November.

And thatâ€™s the end of the session, and this blog. See you tomorrow.. GW

5.56pm GMT

The Treasury Committee have also been considering the issue of Charlotte Hogg, the new deputy governor of the Bank of England who broke its code of conduct by not reporting that her brother works for Barclays bank.

The Committee is due to issue a report on her appointment, and it doesnâ€™t look terribly good for Hogg.

Hereâ€™s the FTâ€™s latest:

Updated at 5.56pm GMT

5.51pm GMT

Q: What impact has the gig economy had on the UK labour market, and on weak wage growth?

Chote says the OBR has made an assumption that self-employment numbers will grow faster than the rest of the labour market (previously it assumed they rose in parallel).

And in the past, increases in self-employment has been â€œmore disadvantageousâ€� than the OBR expected, because many of those jobs were low paid.

5.46pm GMT

Wes Streeting, another Labour MP, asks the OBR about its persistent habit of over-estimating wage growth.

Q: What are you going to do about it?

Robert Chote defends the watchdogâ€™s track record, pointing out that while wage growth has been weaker than forecast, employment growth has been stronger.

So the OBRâ€™s broad assessment of the economy may be right, but the gains are going into new jobs, not higher pay.

5.26pm GMT

John Mann MP asks the OBR about Brexit

Q: What is your projection for a reduction on EU nationals in the years after Brexit?

Robert Chote says the OBR doesnâ€™t make its own forecasts, but it uses projections drawn up by the Office for National Statistics.

5.22pm GMT

Treasury committee chairman Andrew Tyrie asks about the data which the Treasury supplies to the OBR to help it draw up its forecasts.

Q: Why canâ€™t the figures be released publicly? Is there any confidential data about individual taxpayers in there?

The OBR say they donâ€™t see any individual taxpaper information, so that shouldnâ€™t be a problem. But there might be a risk of giving information about tax loopholes.

Robert Chote looks wary of exposing the Treasuryâ€™s numbers to public gaze -- if this happened, ministers might get â€œa lot less candidâ€� about what they told the OBR.

Really, asks Tyrie. We canâ€™t rule out doing anything just because someone might throw a tantrum, he insists.

5.10pm GMT

Charlie Bean: UK is some way from the Laffer Curve tipping point

Back at parliament, Jacob Rees-Mogg MP asks the OBR about the UK tax take.

This is heading towards the highest levels since Harold Wilson was prime minister at the end of the 1960s (at around 38% of national income, I think).

Q: Is it as high as it can get?

Robert Chote points out that many countries have a rather higher tax take, while others have much lower levels.

Q: But arenâ€™t we close to the highest levels appropriate for the UK?

Sir Charlie Bean replies that he suspects we are â€œsome way from the Laffer Curve tipping pointâ€� (where a rise in tax rate brings in less money).

However, â€œwe may be at the political equilibriumâ€�, Bean adds, where politicians wonâ€™t be willing to propose higher tax rates.

5.04pm GMT

Investors wonâ€™t have to worry about article 50 being triggered tomorrow, it seems.

Westminster correspondents are reporting that Theresa May wonâ€™t fire the Brexit starting gun until the end of this month. Scotlandâ€™s push for a new independence referendum may have forced the PM into a delay.

Our political editor Heather Stewart reports:

The government insists this isnâ€™t a u-turn, but Sam Coates of The Times says many wonâ€™t agree:

4.53pm GMT

OBR: No government meddling in our work

Back in parliament, the independent Office for Budget Responsibility is fielding questions on the budget.

Q: Did the OBR come under any undue pressure when drawing up its economic and fiscal outlook, and its assessment of last weekâ€™s budget?

OBR chief Robert Chote says it did not come under pressure from ministers, and all its requests for information from government departments were met.

In the past, we have received â€˜unsolicited submissionsâ€™, Chote smiles - which didnâ€™t feel like pressure compared to some of the actual pressure heâ€™s felt at times.

Q: Now we are moving to one fiscal event a year, rather than two, do we need two statements from the OBR each year?

Sir Charlie Bean, who joined the OBR recently, says it is â€œperfectly reasonableâ€� to think that the second set of economic forecasts should be dropped. That would also limit the temptation for ministers to put pressure on the watchdog.

Q: The chancellor announced a new transitional relief fund to help companies facing higher business rates. How many firms will it actually help?

Chote says the funds will be handled by local authorities, who donâ€™t have much instruction on how to use it. They could provide significant help to the worst cases, or spread the support across more companies. We just donâ€™t know what theyâ€™ll do yet.

That transitional relief will also â€˜taper offâ€™ over the next few years, while business rates are set to rise steadily.

4.44pm GMT

The FTSE 100 index has also closed higher, up 0.3% at 7367.

Mining stocks rallied, following a pick-up in commodity prices.

4.43pm GMT

4.38pm GMT

FTSE 250 index closes at alltime high

Newsflash: Britainâ€™s FTSE 250 index of mid-sized companies has closed at a new record high.

The FTSE 250 finished at 19,029 points, showing that Brexit angst isnâ€™t hitting the markets yet.

The rally was driven by engineering firm Amex Foster, which closed 11% high after agreeing a takeover bid from John Wood.

Housebuilder Bovis, which is being courted by Redrow and Galliford Try, jumped by 9,9%.

4.18pm GMT

Over at parliament, the Treasury committee are questioning the Office for Budget Responsibility over last weekâ€™s Budget.

Robert Chote, head of the independent watchdog is there, along with Sir Charlie Bean and Graham Parker.

Itâ€™s being streamed live here. Iâ€™ll keep an eye out for any early fireworks... (we did hear a lot from the OBR last week).

3.39pm GMT

Dean Turner, economist at UBS Wealth Management, predicts that sterling could get spooked if Scotland does press on with a second referendum (one of Fitchâ€™s five challenges today).

He also believes the independence campaign will need to reassure voters about the economic case for breaking away from the UK, and some more detailed answers (ie, which currency they might use).

Turner writes:

â€œWhile Brexit has, of course, added a new dimension, the economic concerns that led the majority in Scotland to vote to remain a part of the UK have not disappeared. Scottish GDP lags behind the UK and declining oil revenues have raised questions over the fiscal sustainability for an independent Scotland â€“ especially if it intends to retain the pound. While EU membership may provide Scotland with a preferable trade agreement, carving a new membership would be no mean feat and the UK still remains Scotlandâ€™s largest trading partner.

â€œMarket reaction to Sturgeonâ€™s speech has been muted so far, most likely because she still has a long way to go to achieve approval for a second Referendum and the announcement was well-flagged. Yet if approval becomes increasingly likely, we expect volatility in sterling to rise.â€�

2.52pm GMT

The Scottish governmentâ€™s push for a fresh referendum on independence isnâ€™t hurting the pound.

Sterling is holding onto this morningâ€™s gains, and changing hands at $1.223 against the US dollar, up 0.5% today.

Kathleen Brooks of City Index believes traders believe Scotland would vote to remain in the UK (assuming this second referendum actually happens). She says;

A second referendum for Scotland is not a key event risk for UK asset markets right now for a couple of reasons: firstly, Nicola Sturgeon didnâ€™t give an actual date for this referendum, it could happen sometime between 2018 and 2019, which is probably too far in the future for the markets to start worrying and pricing in the break up of the United Kingdom. Also, the latest opinion polls suggest that a second referendum would go the same way as the first, and the majority of voters would choose to stay in the United Kingdom.

While opinion polls still canâ€™t be fully trusted, itâ€™s enough, at this stage, to keep UK markets calm.

Another reason for calm is that the UK government (which must approve the plan) has tried to slap down the idea, saying another referendum would be divisive (!) and cause economic uncertainty (!!).

Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson has tweeted her opposition too.

2.29pm GMT

Draghi: Europe needs to use technology better

European Central Bank Mario Draghi has warned that productivity in the eurozone is being held back because too few firms are embracing new technology.

Opening a conference on â€œFostering Innovation and Entrepreneurship in the Euro areaâ€�, Draghi argues that the future was brighter than coms fear.

He says:

If, as the worldâ€™s second largest economic area, we were to dismantle barriers to innovative activity in the euro area, it would clearly give a boost to global innovation.

Europe, though, has been slower than America when it comes to using new technologies such as computers, Draghi continues:

This is a long-standing issue for the euro area: better adoption of ICT in the United States appears to explain most of the productivity gap between the US and the EU15 from 1995 to 2007.

And small firms, Draghi concludes, need to catch up!

There are many reasons why it is a priority today in the euro area to address weak productivity growth. But while some progress can be made in innovation, it is not in my view the sole issue. Equally important for the euro area is to facilitate and encourage the spread of new technology from the frontier to the laggard firms.

Simply by diffusing better the technology we already have in the euro area, we could make sizeable gains in productivity. In other words, there is much we can still do to reverse the aggregate productivity slowdown and dispel pessimism about our future.

1.40pm GMT

Wall Street has just opened for the week, but thereâ€™s not much excitement.

The Dow Jones index and the S&P 500 have both dipped by a mere 0.01%.

Maybe traders are feeling lethargic after losing an hourâ€™s sleep on Sunday as America moved to Daylight Saving Time (Britain doesnâ€™t make the leap until 26 March).

12.57pm GMT

Concerns raised over UK economic data leaking

Is some UK economic data being leaked before publication, and are some unscrupulous investors profiting?

New research published in the Wall Street Journal this morning suggests that some people in the markets may be making a killing by trading on official reports from the Office for National Statistics before theyâ€™re published.

The WSJâ€™s Mike Bird writes:

UK. government-bond futures often move sharply in the 24 hours before sensitive economic reports are released, an analysis of trading data shows, a phenomenon that suggests some investors may be trading with knowledge of official statistics before they are made public.

On average, between April 2011 and December 2016, U.K. government-bond futures correctly anticipated the rise or fall that ultimately happened when economic data were published, according to an analysis prepared for The Wall Street Journal by Alexander Kurov, associate professor of finance at West Virginia University.

More here: Market Drift Suggests Some Investors May Be Trading on U.K. Economic Data Ahead of Release

ONS reports are typically distributed among more than 100 people in government circles in the run-up to the official publication. And I can remember a few occasions over the years when gilts, or the pound, suddenly rose or fell just before 9.30am (when many ONS reports hit the wires).

Thatâ€™s not proof of a leak, of course. But any hint of wrong-doing is a serious concern.

Sam Bowman, Executive Director of the Adam Smith Institute, wants action:

â€œReports that markets are moving ahead of official ONS data releases in a way that is consistent with leaks and insider trading must be taken extremely seriously by the government and the ONS.

â€œIf flaws in ONS procedures are enabling market-moving leaks to take place, allowing some individuals to profit off secret information, then something has gone badly wrong. The Cabinet Office should review ONS procedures and consider substantial reforms in light of this new evidence.

Bowman argues that Britain could learn from America:

â€œWe could follow the lead of the United States, where these suspicious market movements are seldom seen, and data is released less than 24 hours after completion and statistical reports are physically delivered to the President.

â€œAn alternative option would be to make the process entirely open, so that the public (and the markets) can see ONS data in real-time as it is generated, and markets can price in new information immediately and openly. The ONS is already working on this, but todayâ€™s findings should be an urgent call to action for them to speed up the process.â€�

12.08pm GMT

Up in Edinburgh, first minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced that sheâ€™ll ask the Scottish parliament to vote next on week on whether to hold a second independence vote.

Sturgeon is arguing that Scotland shouldnâ€™t be taken down the path of â€˜hard Brexitâ€™ without being offered the alternative of an independent future inside the EU.

It adds yet another dimension to the Brexit story...but the pound is curiously unmoved by this added political uncertainty.

Updated at 1.31pm GMT

11.41am GMT

Fitch: Now the hard work of Brexit starts

Rating agency Fitch has fired a sobering blast at anyone who thinks Britainâ€™s departure from the EU will be simple.

In a new commentary, James McCormack, Fitchâ€™s Global Head of Sovereign Ratings, outlines five challenges facing Theresa May as she prepared to trigger article 50.

McCormack points out that May doesnâ€™t have the luxury of controlling the agenda of the Brexit talks. This means some leaders can refuse to discuss future trade links, for example, until other contentious issues have been nailed down - such as Britainâ€™s outstanding financial promises to the bloc.

As McCormack puts it:

Lack of full control over the negotiating agenda is the most important of these. While Prime Minister May has said a comprehensive free trade agreement with the EU is one of the governmentâ€™s objectives, some European leaders have suggested that post-exit trade arrangements can only be considered after the terms of exit have been agreed.

A related challenge will be settling the financial terms of the UKâ€™s departure from the EU, which is likely to be among the issues EU leaders seek to resolve up front. The UK will have a strong incentive to settle its â€œexit billâ€� quickly to preserve as much of the two-year negotiating period as possible for more difficult and important issues. But in so doing, it risks criticism at home of an early and unnecessary concession

McCormack also spies three domestic challenges on the horizon, including the prospect of the United Kingdom breaking up.

Scotland may seek a bespoke solution to allow continued access to the single market, raising the risk of a second independence referendum if its objectives are unmet.

Scotlandâ€™s First Minister is giving a speech on Brexit and Article 50 right now! Our Politics Liveblog is on the case:

Related: Nicola Sturgeon delivers speech on Brexit and Article 50 - Politics live

And that still leaves the possibility that some Brexit supporters get cold feet, if negotiations with the EU go badly.

Beyond Scotland, there is certain to be plenty of open opposition to the governmentâ€™s negotiating strategies and priorities, exposing possible political pressure points that can be exploited by EU negotiators.

Finally, it will prove challenging for the government to manage expectations over a two-year period, and negotiating setbacks may be reflected in heightened financial market volatility. The biggest associated risk is a decided swing in public opinion toward a more negative view of Brexit, lending support for either a greater Parliamentary role in approving the final negotiated agreement or another opportunity for the electorate to formally express its view.

Plenty for investors to fret about, then.

Updated at 1.32pm GMT

11.29am GMT

The FTâ€™s Gideon Rachman has written a good piece today about the uncertainty that shrouds Brexit - and worries the markets.

He writes:

Brexit is still shrouded by uncertainty. As one UK official closely involved in the process puts it: â€œSome days I wake up and think itâ€™s all going to be fine. Other days, it feels like a disaster in the making.â€�

I feel the same way. It seems to me likely that Brexit will work out badly for Britain and fairly badly for the EU. But there are so many different variables involved that nobody sensible can be sure. There are three main â€œknown unknownsâ€�. First, the negotiations themselves. Second, events in the wider world. Third, the unpredictable economic effects of what ever deal is struck.

When it comes to the negotiations, both sides are talking tough. The EU is likely to demand a costly â€œdivorce settlementâ€� of up to â‚¬60bn to settle Britainâ€™s unpaid bills and may refuse to discuss a trade deal until the UK has agreed to pay up.

The early British response has been uncompromising. Boris Johnson, the foreign secretary, has evoked the ghost of Margaret Thatcher. He and the Daily Mail will surely soon follow up with references to Winston Churchill. There is a high chance that the money issue will cause negotiations to break down before they really get going.

However, it is also clearly possible that both sides are bluffing, and will back off. The more realistic voices in the UK government understand the dangers of a â€œcliff edgeâ€� Brexit in which the parties fail to agree a deal. And there are costs for the EU too. Britain is Germanyâ€™s third-largest export market......

More here:

10.53am GMT

Anyone caught up in todayâ€™s rail strikes may be due compensation. So this chart from Money.co.uk could be useful:

More info here:

  • Southern Rail: Delay Repay compensation
  • Northern Railways: Delay Repay Application
  • Merseyrail: Refunds and Compensation

Hannah Maundrell, editor in chief of money.co.uk urges passengers to seek compensation:

â€œItâ€™s ridiculous that travelling by train is becoming such a headache.

The only consolation is you can claim a full refund if your train is cancelled and compensation if itâ€™s delayed. Most people donâ€™t know they can get money back from the train company if their travel plans are ruined by strike action. You can fill in a claims form online, it takes 5 minutes and gives you something to do if youâ€™re left standing at the station so itâ€™s definitely worth doing.

Updated at 10.53am GMT

10.42am GMT

Transport workers in Britain and Germany have downed tools this morning, leaving some passengers marooned and others struggling to get to work.

In the UK, the Merseyrail and Northern rail networks have been hit by strike action that affects Liverpool, Leeds, Manchester, Sheffield and Newcastle. Unions are protesting against plans to introduce new trains with doors that can be operated by the driver, rather than guards.

Thatâ€™s on top of (yet another) strike affecting Southern rail, as the ongoing row between unions and management continues.

Related: Rail strikes begin on Southern, Merseyrail and Northern networks

While in Germany, hundreds of flights have been cancelled as airport ground crews hold a 25-hour stoppage. Theyâ€™re calling for a pay increase and better working hours, to reflect an increase in their workloads.

Updated at 1.33pm GMT

10.23am GMT

Anxiety over Wednesdayâ€™s likely US interest rate rise is weighing on Europeâ€™s stock markets this morning.

The UK, French and German trading floors are all rather subdued, meaning the main indices are little changed from Friday.

With a rate hike priced in, investors will be happier when the Federal Reserve meeting is done and dusted.

Chris Beauchamp of City firm IG says:

Anyone wondering why the market is so quiet this morning will have to look no further than the Fed meeting for a reason. Another rate hike could be just days away, indeed, given the way the Fedâ€™s policymakers have been talking, it is practically a certainty at this point. Fridayâ€™s jobs report reinforced the narrative, but the key now will be what the statement and press conference say. As a result we are likely to see the bullish flows that have dominated since the US election pause for breath, at least until Wednesday is out of the way.

Mike van Dulken of Accendo Markets flags up that the drop in the dollar is pushing up commodity prices, and thus shares in miners.

9.54am GMT

The oil price has hit a three-month low this morning.

Brent crude slid to $51.26 per barrel, the weakest level since last November. And â€˜implied volatility ha surged, suggesting traders expect the price to move dramatically in the coming weeks.

The selloff is being driven by signs that Americaâ€™s shale industry is boosting production. Figures released on Friday showed a rise in the number of oil rigs in action, and earlier data showed inventories are building.

This could all undermine the deal hammered out by Opec members last autumn to cut supplies.

9.29am GMT

Currency experts predict that the pound will face further pressure once Theresa May launches Britainâ€™s departure from the European Union.

Bloomberg has a good take. Hereâ€™s a flavour:

â€œWe reject the notion that sterling has fully priced Article 50 and beyond. Risks to the currency remain to the downside on a disruptive start to negotiations,â€� Bank of America Merrill Lynch strategists including Kamal Sharma said in a note to clients on March 2, adding they see a dip before a recovery into the end of the year.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. is also bearish. It recommended on March 3 selling the pound against the dollar at 1.2250, with a stop at 1.2530, as it sees the currency as the most over-valued in the Group-of-10 and investor confidence as vulnerable.

Bank of Americaâ€™s preferred strategy is to bet on greater swings in the pound, rather than its direction. It has recommended buying three-month forward volatility, a measure of expected swings, with a target for it to gain around 20 percent from current levels. Societe Generale SA also sees opportunity in options, as it expects two-month implied volatility to pick up if cable falls below $1.20....

8.58am GMT

FSTE 250 hits record high

Britainâ€™s FTSE 250 index has hit a fresh all-time high this morning, driven by merger activity.

The FTSE 250, which is made up of medium-sized companies, hit 19,048 points in early trading.

The rally is being led by engineering firm Amec Foster, which has surged by 19% after agreeing a takeover offer from larger rival John Wood (which is up 7.5%). Bovisâ€™s gains are also helping.

The FTSE 250 has gained over 25% since the immediate aftermath of last Juneâ€™s EU referendum, defying speculation that the Brexit vote would cause financial trauma and a recession.

Updated at 1.33pm GMT

8.37am GMT

In the City....shares in housebuilder Bovis Homes have surged by 8% in early trading, following takeover approaches from Redrow and Galliford Try.

Although Bovis has rejected both offers, investors clearly suspect that a deal will be done - especially as Bovis is reeling from complaints of shoddy workmanship from hundreds of customers.

Bovis shares are trading around 890p - and Neil Wilson of ETX Capital suggests a winning bid might be rather higher.

Redrowâ€™s offer is valued at Â£8.14 per Bovis share, while Galliford Tryâ€™s is worth 886p per share.

There is a strong chance that one will succeed and that should support the stock. But Bovis should hold out for a better premium. Joint brokers Deutsche Bank and Jeffries have price targets of 969p and 886p respectively. A successful bid might need to at least split the difference to satisfy the board. Although even that might not be enough â€“ only in January Deutsche Bank was targeting 1066p for Bovis. Above Â£10 a share might be more appropriate.â€�

Updated at 8.57am GMT

8.32am GMT

Over in Westminster, the chatter is that Theresa May could trigger Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty on Tuesday.

The prime minister is due to update MP on events at last weekâ€™s EU council meeting tomorrow, and could take the opportunity to get the Brexit ball rolling.

Itâ€™s not quite as simple as that. First, MPs would have to remove amendments inserted into the Brexit legislation by the House of Lords last week, which give parliament the right to veto Mayâ€™s eventual deal.

Parliament is also digesting a warning that Britain would find itself in a dire position if it doesnâ€™t agree a trade deal with Europe. Labour MP Pat McFadden has accused some government ministers of â€œdangerous complacencyâ€�, over their claims that Britain would be fine without a deal.

My colleague Peter Walker explains:

Open Britain, which groups a series of formerly pro-remain MPs from Labour, the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats, said leaving with no deal would mean the UK â€œchoosing the most extreme position of all major trading nationsâ€�.

The research, by the House of Commons library, found that the EU does not currently trade with any G20 member without some sort of preferential trade arrangement in place.

While many of these fell short of full FTAs, some G20 countries, notably Australia and Japan, were now seeking more comprehensive deals, Open Britain said...

More here:

Related: No-deal Brexit 'would put UK in worst trading position of rich nations'

Updated at 9.02am GMT

8.19am GMT

Dollar dips as rate hike looms

After strong US jobs data last Friday, thereâ€™s a strong feeling in the markets that the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates on Wednesday.

That should encourage investors to hold the US dollar, as they can anticipate receiving a higher rate of return.

But...the dollarâ€™s actually down this morning, shedding half a cent against the pound and the euro.

So the pound is trading at $1.222, while the euro hit a one-month high of $1.0699.

Why?

FXTM chief market strategist Hussein Sayed reckons itâ€™s a case of â€œbuy the rumor, sell the newsâ€�.

Investors are almost convinced that the Fed will move forward in tightening monetary policy, with speculators pricing in 89% chance of a rate hike according to CMEâ€™s FedWatch Tool. Sir Charlie Bean replies that he suspects we are â€œsome way from the Laffer Curve tipping pointâ€� (where a rise in tax rate brings in less money). Investors wonâ€™t have to worry about article 50 being triggered tomorrow, it seems. Scotlandâ€™s push for a new independence referendum may have forced the PM into a delay. 6.02pm GMT

Pound recovers some ground after hitting eight week low

Worries about Brexit, as well as a second Scottish referendum, sent the pound to an eight week low of $1.2106 against the dollar. The US currency was also boosted by the prospect of a rate rise from the Federal Reserve on Wednesday.

But sterling has since recovered from its lows, although it is still down 0.47% at $1.2160. Against the euro, the pound has fallen 0.29% to â‚¬1.1435 having earlier been as low as â‚¬1.1382. Joshua Mahony, market analyst at IG, said:

Despite the fact that the pound is hugely undervalued by historical standards, the uncertainty surrounding the future of the UK means we find little to be bullish about for the pound as we face confrontational negotiations. One could be excused for feeling we have had quite enough referendums over the past year, yet with Scotland seeking a second vote, there are plenty of reasons to question what the UK will look like in just over two yearsâ€™ time.

On that note, it is time to close for the evening. Thanks for all your comments, and weâ€™ll be back tomorrow.

A fall in the oil price, uncertainty over Brexit and a second Scottish referendum along with some caution ahead of an expected US interest rate rise on Wednesday and the Dutch election left equity markets in Europe lower on the day. Scottish independence would be negative for UK rating - Fitch

A second Scottish referendum which lead to a vote for independence would be â€œa negative credit shockâ€� for the UK economy and public finances, and could lead to a rating downgrade, according to a new report by Fitch.

The agency, which has a AA rating with a negative outlook on the UK, said:

We believe Scottish independence would have adverse effects on the UK public finances and economy and so would be credit negative for the UK, as we have previously stated. Key uncertainties include the impact on the future trade relationship between the two countries, the financial sector and Scotlandâ€™s currency arrangements.

Scottish independence would lead to an increase in the ratio of UK government debt to GDP. The UK government stated ahead of the September 2014 referendum that it would in all circumstances honour its issued stock of UK debt if Scotland voted for independence.
